description: Borrowed from French witzchoura (obsolete), vitchoura (“witzchoura”), from Polish wilczura (“(archaic) wolfskin”), from wilczy (“wolf-like, lupine”) (ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *wĺ̥kʷos (“wolf”)) + -ura (suffix forming feminine nouns).

entries.meaning: (historical) A woman's fur-lined cloak, mantle, or pelisse with large sleeves, worn during the early 19th century.
